titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Dined at the Minister Count Schulenburg’s with a large diplomatic company.— The late avoyer of Berne Steiger was there— The only person whom I had not met before— Ride in the afternoon. Extremely dusty and sandy, as are all the rides round Berlin, excepting only the road to Potsdam. At the Casino— Letter from Mr: Murray.
2. Finished reading the works of Gesner, with the Letter upon Landscape painting.— Gillies History of Greece— Mr: Childs called this afternoon— Walk with him in the Park— Weather excessively warm.

3. Weather still warm.— Long walk before dinner.— Mrs: Adams to Charlottenburg afternoon.— Am reading many things (too many things) at once.— Hagedorn’s Works, the Preface— A German Poet. His first poem, is a translation of Pope’s Universal Prayer.— He renders every four lines of the original in eight German lines of equal length— Of course the concentration of thought which distinguishes the original is totally lost.— Mirabeau’s Monarchie Prussienne— A perpetual libel upon Frederic. 2.— Gillies— History of Greece— Aristomenes the Messenian.

4. The warmest day we have had this Season.— Thermometer all day at 92. Evening at Bellevue. Casino, with Madame de Grappendorf, Mlle: Hagen and M. de Caström— Prince Ferdinand asked me if I had yet become acquainted with Count Cobenzel, who arrived here yesterday.— Says he is a remarkable good stage player, and excels in the character of valets— He used to perform before the Empress of Russia, when he was Austrian Minister at that Court— The Prince said he thought it not perfectly suitable to the grave character of an Ambassador.

5. Mr: Kent and Mr: Hamilton called, to fix upon the time of our departure for Potzdam to-morrow. We agreed upon 4. in the afternoon— Went with Mrs: Adams to Charlottenburg, and brought back with us Isabella Brown, who is to go with us to Potzdam— Severe thunder shower this morning.— The only one of like force that we have witnessed here.— Trying to read Buchholz’s history of the Electorate of Brandenburg as a German exercise— Begin with the 6th: and last volume containing the reign of Frederic II.

6. At about 5 in the afternoon we started for Potsdam— Mr: Childs was with us, and in company with us three English Gentlemen, Messrs: Kent, Jarratt and Hamilton— The first a clergyman who accompanies Jarratt upon his travels— He is the son of a wealthy Jamaica planter— Mr: Hamilton is a young man, going to pass some time at Göttingen.— William Brown and my brother went on horse-back.— We arrived at Potsdam before nine in the Evening— The distance 4 German, about 16 english miles; in two stages The road very good— a turnpike made at great expence over the sands of the Country— We lodge at the sign of the Hermit.

7. Took the whole forenoon to see the various objects of curiosity in and round Potsdam— The Gallery of Pictures, not a large collection but containing some very good paintings of the first masters in the flemish and Italian schools.— The palace of Sans Souci, with an imitation of ruins built in the midst of an hanging wood on the side of an hill about a quarter of a mile distant from it.— This was a favourite residence of Frederic II, and behind the palace are buried his dogs, each of them being honoured with a grave stone. There are several writing chambers, and libraries in two of them, which he was wont to use— The books were all french—many of them translations from greek, latin, Italian and English authors—but not so much as the name of a German.— The Belvidere is a small building like a summer house, near Sans-souci, commanding an extensive prospect. The new Palace, a large and expensive one, built by Frederic II. just after the close of the seven years war
to prove (so they say) that his resources were not exhausted— The marble Palace, so called because partly constructed of that material, was built by the late king, and is not yet completed.— It is internally the most convenient, and most in a modern stile— Rather elegant than superb.— The late king died there, and in one of his apartments we found still a bust of the Countess of Lichetenau.— We saw near it the house in which she was for some months confined, after his death.— In the garden we saw a couple of buildings externally like a peasant’s hut and a rough grotto, with handsome and well furnished apartments within.— In the Palace were a number of antique statues, purchased in Italy, by order of the late king, in the year 1791.— It was near four o’clock when we returned quite fatigued to our Inn— William Brown, returned in the evening to Berlin— I read Clery’s account of the captivity of Louis 16. which Mr: Kent had with him.

8. Saw the guards performing their usual exercises in the Palace garden, at eleven this morning.— Went upon the steeple of the garrison church, from which there is an extensive and very beautiful prospect.— But we could not see the monuments of Frederic William I. and Frederic II. who are buried here, under the pulpit.— We went over the orphan house— The dining hall and bed rooms are quite decent there are about 400 boys and not quite so many girls here—from 6 to 14 years of age, after which they are put out as apprentices, to trades.— We were detained here sometime by a severe thunder shower.— It prevented us also from returning this evening, as we had intended to Berlin.— In the afternoon we went to see the manufacture of small arms, belonging to Schickler.— but the barrels are made at Spandau. We saw them only bore a touch-hole, and make a breech-pin.— We finished the day by going over the Palace in the town, which contains scarcely any thing of remark. Nothing indeed but another of Frederic the II’s libraries consisting entirely of french books. We opened a volume of his own works, and fell upon a poem in which he says

But from the appearance of all his libraries, it must have been the charming translation of Sanadon that inspired him, for in all his collections there was not an original Horace, or any other classical author to be found.— We observed here too a picture of Dido and Aeneas that was tolerable— The figure of Cupid in the shape of Ascanius in the Lady’s lap was good— Evening at our inn.

9. Took a walk with the gentlemen, before breakfast, to the ruins built by Frederic II. opposite Sans Souci. artificial ruins cannot be very pleasing, and these appear to advantage only, at a distance, peering out from among the trees— After breakfast we took our departure for Berlin, all but Mr: Kent and Mr: Jarratt, who at the same time set out for Dessau, in prosecution of their travels. between two and three o’clock we reached home;—found letters from Mr: Murray, and news from America— Mr: Lutze from Stettin had called upon me.— He came again at 5 in the afternoon, and I delivered to him his Commission & Instructions as Consul of the United States at that Port— A couple of hours this Evening at the Casino.— Head ache.

10. Mrs: Adams unwell— Visits from Mr: Childs and Mr: Hamilton.— In the Evening at Count Zinzendorf’s; party not large—most of the usual company is now in the Country. Stayed not long.— Upon coming home found the young Countess Neale— Weather extremely warm.
11. Mrs: A. yet ill.— Letter to Mr: Murray.— Reading Buchholz.— Mirabeau— Gillies History of Greece &c— Long walk at the beginning of the Evening.

12. Weather continues very warm.— Mr: Hamilton and Mr: Childs dined with us— Walked afterwards with the latter to the Wilhelm-platz; at the four corners of which are the Statues of the generals Schwerin, Keith, Winterfeld, and Seydlitz, erected by Frederic II. and in the centre that of Von Zieten erected by the late king.
Mlle. Neale spent the evening with Mrs. A— I went in and looked over the Roman Catholic church of St: Hedwige.— a Rotundo— Small but very neat and elegant within.

13. My brother and Mr: Childs set off this morning for Dresden— Weather extremely warm.— Casino— Walk with Mr: Richards under the Linden— Conversation— Continue reading the book upon the Prussian monarchy, Struensee was son of a clergyman at Halle.— Was called to Denmark and employed at the time when his brother was in high credit there— Upon his fall was arrested— Frederic II. claimed him as one of his subjects.— He was released— Came to Potzdam, and Frederic after a conversation with him, which discovered his talents gave him a place at Elbing— He was afterwards placed in a subordinate Station in the direction of the Maritime Society. On the accession of the late king and retirement of Count Schulenburg, Struensee was placed at the head of the maritime Society, ennobled and made a Minister of State, with the administration of the excise, which he still holds.

14. Weather continues excessively warm— Mr: Hamilton called— He goes to morrow morning, with Mr: Hawkins, an antiquarian traveller lately returned from Greece— Evening at the Pic-nic— Madame de Grappendorf, and the chamberlain Baron de Reck.— Monsr: Dorville invited us for next Tuesday.— Walk in the park— Young Countess Neale, Evening and supper.

15. At the play this Evening. Doctor Tonnuccio, a dull thing; and “the mourning, or Steward deceived.” a farce from the french of Hauteroche, or the English “ghost.”— Met the Comte Schall there.— I understood somewhat more of the dialogue, than I have heretofore.— But I still find the difficulties of the language excessive.

16. Buchholz is too dry and uninteresting to learn the language by. There is no attraction that continually draws one to the book.— Flaming taught me more German in one month, than all the rest of my studies since I have been here.— I must return to novels.— Procured for this purpose Schiller’s Ghost-seer and commenced upon it this afternoon— At the Casino. Met there M. de Sartoris.

17. Reading this morning the novel of Schiller, and find immediately the difference of application proceeding from a different degree of interest in the book— Read more of it again in the Evening. Mrs: Adams went this afternoon with the young Countess Neale, to Charlottenburg.

18. The Queen held a Court at Charlottenburg this afternoon at 5 o’clock—attended it— She was very pleasant and agreeable— Weather very bad for it— Rained all the afternoon— Find one part of my new German book again extremely difficult— Got over it very superficially.— A long argument upon free-will, necessity, and the like metaphysical subtleties, which would be almost unintelligible even if I were master of the language— It takes up 60 or 70 pages. The rest is easy enough.

19. Finished the first volume of the Ghost-seer—read over again and mastered the metaphysical disquisition which I found so difficult yesterday.— Evening at the Chamberlain Baron de Reck’s.— A party for the Princess Henry. Letters from Mr: King and Mr: Murray.—

20. Miss Dorville and Miss Neale, were here this afternoon— Evening at the Princess Henry’s weekly party— Whist with Madam Parella, Madamand the marquis de Musquiz.— reading the second volume of the Ghost-seer; but it is by another and a very inferior hand.
21. Called this afternoon at half past five, upon Count Haugwitz, and had some conversation with him. Miss Neale— Evening at the Pic Nic— Mr: Dorville’s— Home early.

22. Not perfectly well— Mr: Garlike called on me— Interesting conversation with him— Long walk before dinner.— In the afternoon at the Casino— Reports of an action between the English and french fleets in the mediterranean, unconfirmed—
23. In the evening, at Bellevue— Company almost altogether of Men. Whist with Mlle: Hagen, the Marquis de Musquiz, and Mr: Constant.— Began the 3d. volume of the Ghost-seer.—
24. At a party this Evening given to the Princess Henry, at General Kunheim’s. Did not stay long. Read a couple of Brydone’s letters again after returning home.
25. It rained almost the whole day; with a storm of wind.— Writing letters— An hour this Evening at the Casino.— Reading Brydone upon my return.

26. Rained and stormed the greatest part of this day. Dined at Doctor Brown’s at Charlottenburg— The news of last week proves all false. Finished this Evening, the third and last volume of the Geisterseher. The two last are dull and tedious attempts merely to fill the chasms of the first. the object of which is to excite wonder in the highest degree, and leave the whole story covered with a thick veil.

27. Long walk in the park.— Twice at the Casino.— English reviews.— Began to read the Menschenhass und Reue, of Kotzebue— I saw it performed about two years ago, at the Hague, in low Dutch.— It is one of the most celebrated modern German Comedies.—

28. Finished reading the Menschenhass und Reue, this morning, and in the course of the day began, a novel called Rudolph von Werdenberg by Lafontaine, the author of Flaming’s life and adventures. The weather quite cold— Evening partly at the Casino, reading the English reviews.

29.— Went to the play this afternoon, to see “Oberon, king of the fairies.” But the house was so full that we could get no places. Ride afterwards with Mrs: A.—half an hour at the Casino.— Continuing Brydone’s tour.—
30. My brother returned this morning from Dresden— Weather continues as it has been several days very cold— Flakes of snow.— Walk— Met Mr: Garlike— At the Casino this Evening— English papers.

31. Weather yet cold and rainy, with thunder showers— Had no sleep last night— At the play this Evening. “Two Uncles for one,” a farce, and the village barber an opera, each in one act. Pleasant music. Understood something of the Dialogue.

Day. Rise between 7 and 8—read German till 10. Breakfast. read and write till 2. Walk—dine 1/2 past 3. read again after dinner, an hour— At the Casino or in company.— close the Evening as heretofore. I have for the last half of this month resumed my German studies with revived application, and find the facility of reading gradually increase— I find some encouragement in my progress hitherto; and hope to persevere untill I can read the language with perfect ease.
